description: Borrowed from Latin coāgulō, coāgulātus, from coāgulum (“a means of curdling, rennet”), from cōgō (“bring together, gather, collect”), from co- (“together”) + agō (“do, make, drive”). Doublet of quail. Displaced native Middle English irennen, from Old English ġerinnan, but not native curdle.

verbs.description: coagulate (third-person singular simple present coagulates, present participle coagulating, simple past and past participle coagulated)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become congealed; to convert from a liquid to a semisolid mass.
examples: In cheese making, milk coagulates into curds that become cheese.
Rennet coagulates milk; heat coagulates the white of an egg.

entries.meaning: A mass formed by means of coagulation.
